author: Jay Schreiber
title: Kershaw’s Task on Short Rest Is Nothing Compared to What His Mentor Accomplished
text:
If Clayton Kershaw needs any inspiration as he heads to the mound tonight to face the Mets on three days’ rest, he can look to Sandy Koufax, the Dodgers left-hander who was even more dominant than Kershaw.
After all, it was 50 years ago Wednesday that Koufax pulled off what might have been the greatest feat of his Hall of Fame career. Pitching on just two days’ rest, in Game 7 of the World Series, Koufax shut out the Minnesota Twins on three hits in a taut 2-0 victory.
Koufax pitched the entire game, nearly unthinkable now, but not then. And just three days earlier, in Game 5, Koufax shut out the Twins, 7-0, allowing four hits. That one, needless to say, was a complete game, too.
Koufax had been forced into that condensed timetable because he had famously skipped Game 1 of the Series because it fell on Yom Kippur, a Jewish holy day.
